number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												About the game:This game is a slow-paced game, as reflected by the slow story expansions released since 2007 (7 yrs is long time in the gaming world).  It took 7 years to reach Two Towers storyline and it doesn't really have much emphasis on PVP action. It's your traditional quest/crafting MMORPG.My experience:I played LOTRO for a fair bit of time. I started off to be F2P but soon realized I just cannot make any reasonable progress after reaching Moria. The most important issue was travelling. It just took too damn long given it's such a big virtual world and especially in Moria area where you can easily drop off cliffs if you're not paying attention. You need premium accounts to unlock many travel points. Without fast travel, you can easily expect watching yourself traveling for 10+mins. It just doesn't make sense for this day and age. Pros:- It's Middle-Earth!!- HUGE world, lots to do and explore- Friendly community, it's one of the best online gaming community I've met for all the games I've played- Classes are well balanced- Crafting system is cool, class system restricts what type of raw materials you can harvest/refine so you're going to have multiple characters for sure in this gameCons:- Horrible, sometimes buggy in-game purchase interface. Too slow and often resets.- Progress is too slow, both in leveling and providing storyline- Really difficult to complete some quests without a good party- Traveling is a pain- Because of travelling cost, quest planning also is a pain because you want to clear all the quests in the same small area- Mapping system needs to be improved, I like the maps following the literature artwork. But practically speaking, I need to be able to zoom in/out to really see where I need to go!- Quest grinding, too many of the quests are collect-style quests.- This game takes TIMEConclusion:I only really enjoyed the game when I had the premium subscription. In the long run it's just too much $$ (expect to invest $100+ in the long run). It just isn't a good investment to me, especially recent explosion in F2P games. On the other hand, I can pay Dragon Age $50 upfront knowing I won't need to keep paying to unlock slightly more gameplay.Therefore, sadly at this current date, I cannot recommend this game unless they overhaul the game mechanics/graphics to provide more action/$ and quality/$. It is getting outdated compared to other MMORPG. One or two yrs ago, I'd recommend this game. If you're rich, then go for it, full premium players enjoys this game a lot more.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												This game used to be an amazing game. But then the fire nation attacked. But nah, after each expansion it got progressively worse. Only the first two were good. Overall though I had fun. The mechanics are great, the questing is fun (Even though all you do is run around the entire land). Unfortunately the PvP is not free... It's a big downside for those looking forward to it. It's also extremely easy to be spoiled by being able to use resources to easily complete quests when they should be challenging and require group effort. In addition, servers are not that populated, so becareful when choosing one. It is possible to get to level 95 in less than a month of hard questing and with the help of another person. The environment is fantastic and incorporates a lot of Tolkien's work with accuracy.Over all I give this game a B- (or a 8.1 out of 10)

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This game is great to try up until level 20. Once at level 20 however, you have the option of becoming a premium or a VIP. Although the game is set up as free to play, it's quite difficult to do much if you aren't at least a premium up to level 20. Your currency is limited, a lot of your inventory is limited, the vault is limited, and you don't feel quite free.What I find troubling about this game is that there is a strong suggestion to pay money to advance. Not even to beat others, but to just advance further into the game and level up. They highly recommend you to use real life money to exchange for their currency (turbine points) or to subscribe monthly for VIP status.That being said, the monthly payments aren't too bad, roughly $10-$15, which is about normal. The quality of the game itself is quite fun. There is quite a lot to do, and each character feels really diversified. It does feel cluttered at times though, due to the high number of repeatable quests and lack of structure for quest taking (grab whatever quest you see, run to it). The main quest doesn't feel too prioritized, but it is a decent story line. At times, it feels like you are just being led around by your quests, rather than pursuing them. They feel really one dimensional, but necessary.The largest appeal of this game is the characters themselves, and the level of customization for your abilities, play style, looks, and classes. I really enjoyed this bit. There are specific skill trees you can specialize in, and they're diverse enough that they don't feel like the same class with different specs. Another thing about skills and abilities is that there is the Deed Log, which keeps track of achievements. This is a great concept of the game that rewards you well for doing specific achievements, which feels very rewarding. This adds to the customization appeal, where you can pursue an achievement to get a skill and be satisfied.In short, I would suggest playing this game at least up until level 20, and to really investigate the skill trees, the deed logs, and traits. Also, experiment with different classes, each class feels very unique, and within each class, is a sub-class that is also unique in a sense.

The community on the game seem rather nice, unlike some other games in which i played where its filled with 13 year boys going through hormonal changes and trying to rip each others eyes out. This is just my inital review, and once i play some more i will most likely add to it. Check the game out.. its free.. if you dont like it.. uninstall it and move on.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Enjoy stunning vistas renderd in low poly models and flat textures. marvel at hand drawn maps expertly crafted to offer no information at all. wonder about where the quest marker actually is. Enjoy unskipable cinematics paced by narcoleptics. read a whole lot of words about things you don't care about. Solve the challenging puzzles of the User interface. be stunned by exciting battle messages like "you must face the target" and "can't do that while moving". Seriously, it's not surprising this game is free to play; what's surprising is that anyone ever had the gual to charge for it, or that it took as long as it did to go free. it's almost 8 years old, shows every single minute of it and then some. The original Guild Wars (now long since shut down) predates it by 2 years, and surpasses it in every single aspect. Not even worth free.

In have spend most of a full day reading up on the basics of LOTRO, and I can say that, whilst the game looks amazing from the outside, I found the time I spent just reading the basic gameplay, the commands, keyboard shortcuts, actions etc. etc took up so much of my time that I only spent around forty minutes playing the actual game.I also found myself having difficuty actually getting the game to start and once it did, there was no sound on the intro but it looked good all the same.Maybe I'm just an old fart but, as an avid gamer, I want to spend more time actually playing a game rather than trying to learn all the rules and do's/don'ts of a game.I'm afraid this game was not for me but in saying that, the game itself looks great (If you're into that kinda thing)!  More of an RTS fan myself.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												I’ve only played a couple of hours at this stage, up to level 10.The storyline and lore was fairly immersive apart from the occasional out of place line of dialogue, the graphics are definitely low budget so don’t expect too much out of it.As for the gameplay itself, the character that I played had standard WoW style combat with channelled spells, instant casts and a ‘white damage’ melee attack.Movement and camera control was almost identical to WoW too down to the num lock for auto walk.I guess that you could say that the learned biases they utilised allowed me to jump right in without much learning, but it also made the experience feel like a cheap independent version of WoW.In a good free to play model the ‘free’ players are used as tools to drive the in-game economy or gameplay, add value for paying player. For example Valve uses free players in TF2 and Dota2 to drive demand -through trading- for paying players to open chests (See Steam Dev Days for more info). In this respect free players are valuable in both a commercial and community sense.But as a new player only a few hours in, it feels like free players are not valued at all. From what I've seen, in-game purchases are in your face within the first 10 minutes of play and it just gets worse from there.In conclusion The Lord of the Rings Online feels like a $5 independent title trying to bleed you dry, with its only redeeming features being the large amount of content. It is also incorrectly labelled free to play, it’s more like a demo for a subscription game with mandatory DLC expansions and pay to win mechanics.

Posted: December 19, 2014
												The F2P model in this game is completely broken and geared towards making you pay a monthly subscription. You will not enjoy this game unless you sub.If you want a good F2P model (not necesarily a good game, that is subjective), take a look at SWTOR. You can choose not to subscribe, make some one-time purchases, and play 90% of the game subscribers play. Total cost: less than 100 US dollars.What does $100 get you in LOTRO? Some zones. Which should have been unlocked in the base F2P game, for starters.Yeah, no.

You're doing quest on an area and when done you have to back your quest region to bring 'em to NPCs. But problem is starting here. They are giving to you Quests which would be done in same place, last time you did. So back to same area. Turn back to quests and again!! There is no logical thing about this. Piece of piece you must do same nonsense. If you played in Evendim (as a sample! most area is same) you should know "High King's Crossing" and "Barad Tharsir" Travels like that. Quest receive location is "HKC"Quest bring location is "BT"And start: HKC>BT>HKC>BT>HKC>BT>HKC ... around 3 hours and done all quest in that area.. Another quest like speak quest. Talk to Aragorn>Talk to Elrond>Aragorn>blabla name>Aragorn>Elrond>Aragorn -_-' So that problem is taking long way travel progress is boring! Maps allready huge (If you played wow you should know wow maps are simple and easily can do) This game past many years and there is nothing improved for lotro. Same graphics, same boring stuff like quests, walks. I personally bought Evendim pack with Quad pack. However I cannot use those region "swift travelling" That is another stupid things. I hope I could be explained what's I mentioned about. Only stupid quest system is making this game so worse.If you have patient and jobless person (so I'm) l I can recommend this game. But there is always better a MMO aka WoW. It's up to you.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												Despite my bias of being a big LOTR fan, and having loved the movie adaptations (not so much the Hobbit, but even those movies were handled well), I find that this game tries too much to pander to my nerdy side rather than the part of me that wants to play a game.My expectation was that I'd make a character and be able to play an adventure where'd I'd be behind the back of my player and control how they fight. I did not get everything on this list.The point and click aspect of this game is the source of why I don't like it. If this game allowed full immersion into fighting by pressing different buttons, then it would be much more fun. What it does instead is say 'Hey, you wanna kill that wolf. You gotta click it and watch your guy attack it'. Really?If I wanted to click and watch the game do the work, I'd be playing Clash of Clans right now.Final Verdict, this game is a disappointment. To me, it doesn't deserve all of the praise it gets, because it's just plain boring. It's lore and story are spot-on to Tolkien's story, but I play a game more for fun than for the story it tells. Normally a story is a big slice of the rating pie for me, but gameplay is always the part I judge the most, and that slice of the pie was bitter for this game.Final Mark: 1/5

number of helpful: 12 of 27 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												Downloaded this game to try it and after a few hours I can say it's not my cup of tea.From the moment you enter the game it is trying to sell you things that, in my honest opinion, should be free.Riding skill should be free and class choices should never be locked behind paywalls.Don't get me wrong, I am more than happy to pay for cosmetics and xp boosts, etc, I do it all the time in other games, but as soon as I am prevented from accessing what I consider core game mechanics I immediately hate the game.Yes, the game is free to play but honestly there are far superior games like Tera, Archage, and swtor that wipe the floor with lotro in both gameplay and graphics, and while this game would have looked fantastic back when it was first launched, in 2016 I expect much more, even from free games.For these reasons I have uninstalled this game and cannot recommend it to any serious MMO players looking to invest their precious life hours.

												I have a realy long history with this game.Like I played it from the very beginning and the first 2 years after it's went F2P.Recently I poped in again and I could barely hold my breakfest.The devs completly ruined the game with changing the bare essence what made it great.Instead of the the specific Skill mechanics that allowed you to optimice your character in different ways, trough experiementing and putting in the right klass abilitys, put they in skill trees, to make the game easier.This had as an result, that they removed a buttload of skill and made the fights an incredible bland 4 skill game.Raids and Dungeons have been simplified, to make sure everything is a DPS race with AoE's everywhere.Tactics are broken down to a bare minimum.If I see the differnces between the last Raids I played and Dunhoth T2, i would say the difficulty,tactic and skill level have droped at around 3000%Honestly, there're better MMO's out there, this might actualy be at the bottom of the barrel.What a fall from one of the best to one of the worst.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												I didn't give this game much of a chance to be honest. I can enjoy 8 bit games and have a blast, but when games try to look good and make a mess out of it by cutting corners I just can't stand to look at the screen. With DX11 and all turned on this game just falls short visually. It's the textures on the toons that just feel, well... cheap, like they cut corners to just push out anything. The micro transactions are out of control. Seems like anything I clicked on wanted me to go to a website and buy coins to spend in game to get items.Hardly no voice overs, in modern MMO's voice overs are a huge part of the games. This might as well be a old final fantasy game with all the text and lack of voice. The in game movies were also very low budget, and this is coming from a guy who mixes his own stuff for youtube. I'm no animater but I can comment as a player and they were terible. Many older games have done far better.Because of these I honestly didn't give the game much of a chance to impress me further. After all, I'm not paid to review games so if it's not something that's fun and catches my interest then no need to continue.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												The download and instillation process took a very long time, perhaps because I installed the optional texture packs. However, once in game, the graphics looked extremely dated, and were hard to look at. That's fine, I've played uglier MMOs. Yet, the combat felt wonky, as every mob ran through me, and the game won't let you attack from behind, so for every single mob I had to walk backwards, then attack. Camera movement was also really bad. The whole time I felt like I had tunnel vision, since I'm use to MMOs that are more friendly with both movement and visibility.Also, every minute or so there is a reminder of what you need to buy in the store. If you're training skills, you should buy this item. If you're collecting valor, you should buy this item. If your character looks ugly, you should buy this item (though there's no item to buy to make the game look good in general). If you want to play with others, you should buy this expansion. It just goes on and on.This is also one of the most dated looking games, both graphically, and in gameplay mechanics. There are just a lot of things that the MMO developer community has stopped doing, and for good reason that make this game seem more dated than it actually is. For instance, you need to level a character that you care nothing about to level 10 before you can make an evil faction character. This sort of nonsensical restriction I've seen in other games, and it's always a bad idea, costing them players in the process.Basically, I stopped playing because of a lot of annoyances heaped on top of each other. The game isn't worth the long download and patching process.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Do not recommend for standard MMO. This game bored me to death from the bad opening tutorial to the random plopping of the main UI. The fighting and game mechanics feel a bit clunky. The camera controls glitched out on me too. I'd recommend other MMOs like Rift. However, if you're looking for an MMO where Lord of the Rings fans can gather and play in, then this is the only MMO you can get. content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												3/10This game embodies the logic of grabbing money in almost any way possible, while still waving the banner of F2P, more than any other game that I have seen. Everything seems fine for the first 10-12 levels. But during these leves you are still in the starting region and you already realise what is going wrong: you have to pay in order to purchase "Turbine Points" in order to be able to play this game in a semi-decent manner. You can't even have more that 2 gold pieces in your wallet without requiring an "Unlimited Wallet Upgrade" which costs 395 Turbine Points alone! You also need those points to unlock other regions and content, the auction house, extra slots for traits (rpg elements giving you character bonuses), to purchase more character slots, to unlock new classes. 90% of the content is available for Turbine points, making this one of the most obvious "pay to win" games I have ever seen.I only rate this game 3/10 because it has some really good mechanics (as for example unlocking traits with achievements),is based on my favorite fantasy setting and if it changes it's money-acquiring mechanisms (in other words if you don't need Turbine Points for everything) it could be one of the best MMORPG games available on the market.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Lord of the Rings Online hasn't captivated players as World of Warcraft has, and there are reasons for that. After playing the game again after the remake of the classes, there some personal reasons I have as to why LOTRO isn't so great.1.  Early Levels - This is a big problem for Lord of the Rings in my opinion, because the early stages of the game are incredibly boring. When you play as a Human, you are hunting down spiders and bandits from level 1-20-ish. Afterwards, the game picks up slightly by introducing the Barrow-Wights but the bandits will still appear from time to time. The Elf and Dwarf starting areas are a little interesting because it involves goblin invasions and shaky alliances between the two races, though it also involves killing wolves and birds from time to time. The Hobbit starting zone is by far the most utterly dull place in the game. I spend most of my times carrying pies from town to town, delivering mail and helping people with their chores. 2. Enemy Design - This might not turn people off as much as it did to me, but the enemy designs are recycled. If they aren't, then someone put a lot of work in for nothing. The fact that the only difference between a bandit in the tutorial and a demon bandit overlord in the shadowy pits of Mordor is only their number, gives the impressions that no-one seemed to give a♥♥♥♥♥♥in the design of the game. 3. F2P is a Lie - Okay, this might be an exaggeration since developers need money and they can't just make the game completely free. Turbine doesn't seem particular successful with their MMOs. I believe their sister MMO, Dungeons and Dragons Online at launch was about to fail miserably (don't quote me on this. They decided to convert LOTRO and DDO into a F2P model worked, at least for a short while. The game promises that you can unlock game content by grinding for Turbine Points but the rate in which you gain Points is painfully slow. The F2P model added some juice to LOTRO but you basically have to grind the early levels over and over to play the next area in each play through. Referring to the first point, the early levels are boring as hell, so your patience will get tested.If you have never touched an MMO before and/or also a fan of Tolkien's work, go ahead and try the early levels. If you want to access the higher-level content, I hope you are willing to pay because grinding and grinding will take away any interest you have for this game.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Garbage MMO was on my hard drive for a record low 20 minutes.  I played before a while ago and it worked decent IIRC.  This time, intro movie was laggy beyond watching.  When that painful crapfest was over, I got to the character creation screen... where I was unable to click on ANY of the buttons.  There were a few forum threads suggesting this and that... mostly tweaking with settings in various files... and the LEAST helpful of all: Click the options button and set graphix to DX9.  Well, there is NO options button on the character select screen and even IF there was one, I would not be able to click on it.  After combing the forums and knowledge bases for "fixes" and "workarounds", uninstall it went.  Which is too bad because 1) I am a big LOTR fan and 2) I had some money I was willing to spend on the game.  Thank god I decided to try the free version and didnt just buy one of the starter packs like I initially thought about doing.  Absolute crap.  Developers clearly can not keep up with evolving PC technology on this dated client.  Move on to something else.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												It's a decent enough MMORPG when you start out. The problem arises when you start to want things like auction house slots and the removal of the extremely hindering gold cap. Almost all of the things you would expect from a game like this have been locked behind a pay wall or restricted to paying subscribers. Turbine Points are the in-game store's currency and are almost essential when playing this game, and they can either be collected by completing "deeds" (tasks which require hours upon hours of grinding) or bought with real money. This is the largest flaw the game has, because after a certain point everything becomes blocked off except for a few main storyline quests.I'm sure this game was great when it was first released, but now that it has gone "F2P" (which is almost a lie) everything revolves around getting Turbine Points to progress. By the time you've collected enough for one small thing, the enjoyment has been ruined.My advice: Play for a bit if you must, but don't spend too much time farming TP, you'll just regret it. Also, If you're considering spending ANY money on this game, please don't. Look at the bigger picture, and go buy a complete experience elsewhere.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												WHEN the game works, it is a run of the mill, standard MMOG.  In fact, its nearly as old as WoW, and its age is starting to show.The best thing it has going for it is the story/setting.  The Free-to-play part is also very good, since you can earn points/currency to unlock everything in the game... It would take you a year or 2 playing nearly non-stop, but the option is there.  Unlike many other F2P MMOGs that you can "play" but some content will always be locked away until you pay.As far gameplay, game mechanics and interface, this game is "Ok" to "Good"However, this is all overshadowed by the terrible software and support.  A lot of the programs that are running in the backgroud have issues with Windows 7 and 8, Anti-virus software also takes issues with the installer/update program.  Add to all this that TURBINE ( the guys who run the game ) use a lot of lesser-known suport software to do all these functions/update.... the problems never gets fixed.  I had currently been playing for about 2-3 years, but the installer/updates often gave me issues, sending me hunting all over the forums for the "fix"... Typically the solutions was to disable firewals, Anti-virus, Windows protector, Nortin or whatever I was using at the time.  Even still, sometimes that wouldn't work.  Aslo, a fresh install was needed nearly every 3 months, meaning a 5-10GB download.I had hoped that a fresh install using Steam would solve the problems, but after a week of trying, I have not yet been able to get it to work.  So why should I spend hours trying to get this to run, when so many other games are just as good or better, free and are work the first time?

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												I really like this game, but only because I am a huge Lord of the Rings fan. The map is really good, and the story is quite good in places: they succesfully combine your character's story to the actual story that we all know and love. The gameplay is just normal MMO gameplay, and the classes are just normal MMO classes. However, the PVP is not very well developed, the mobs are average most of the time, but the worst part is the trait tree update. It means that each character is limited to one tree of skills, and so the skills that all the characters would have had before have been split up in an attempt to encourage group play. However, all it does is make it frustrating that you can't have all the skills, and make the game about leveling up rather than enjoying it. However, the map is the best I have seen in an MMO, they have got all the place names with huge amounts of accuracy, and the map is close to the right size (despite the horses needing to be sped up to cross it without boredom.) Finally, the group quests and instances are fun (if you can assemble a group), and the items are relatively varied. Also, if you want to get above level 34, then you need to enjoy grinding or have quite a bit of cash, because you have to unlock the other areas. That is the worst part of the game, if you ask me.Overall however, I think it's a fun game, but can recognise the large amounts of missing features and the huge room for improvement.

number of helpful: 6 of 16 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												While not a BAD MMORPG, I have to say as a Tolkien fan I was a little saddened by how linear the gameplay felt. "Go here to start the quest, talk to this person to complete the quest, kill exactly this many creatures to complete the quest"...It just doesn't feel as if anything you do has any real impact on the world. If they had given it more of a sandbox feel while still being story driven (think Skyrim or Oblivion), I think I might have enjoyed it more, and yes I understand that a lot of MMOs are limited in this way. I suppose I was just expecting a little more from an established series; I get more enjoyment and feel more freedom in Star Trek Online. Visually and thematically it was appealing and I did love seeing the various locations, but it wasn't for me--especially after taking nearly 48 hours to complete the initial install as well as patch it. LotR fans might enjoy it if they are looking for something that's just LotR themed to play with friends, but if you're looking for something that feels like a Middle Earth experience you probably won't find it here.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												It WAS a really good game that eventually lost touch with most of the older playerbase... not to mention p2w features, which, according to devs were just there for covenience since you could get them grinding for a couple of years as well. And then there were the... well... people who took advantage of a lack of banning. What about getting a fully buffed PvP monster character in one week (something that playing by the rules usually takes a year or more, five years in the old system).Played it for a good four years before I quit. Yes it is Tolkien, Yes it is LotR... but it became tedious with no real challenge (soloing raids anyone), borked updates, broken characters getting fixed then broken again the next day. As in all MMOs there are fixes and changes made all the time... yet time after time Turbine managed to brake things, or fixed things that weren't broken. Or introduced an extremely silly grind to reduce the grind needed to get maxed out buff. And lets not even talk about the lack of raids... If you look for a serious MMO you should look elsewhere, not even the fact that this is ME will save it

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Veredict: Not worth the time and effort.Sorry Tolkien fans, but sadly this is a big No-No.This game is basically World of Warcraft reskinned to look like Lord of the Rings. With some "cameos" from classical characters from the saga.I was a fan of Tolkien's work when I was a kid, read pretty much everything there is to read, and watched the movies when I was almost outgrowing Middle Earth. And to a lesser degree, I was a fan of pretty much everything Blizzard did up until recently. This is to clarify that I am more than aware of the "lore" differences.The problem is with the "feel" of the game. The gameplay feels clunky, the LotR lore feels heavyhanded, and the graphics barely offer anything remarkable (but they get the job done). And eventually, if you really want to experiencie everything there is to experiencie, you will have to pay... so it's not really "free" free. Now, I'm not saying that you cannot play without paying, or that this is a pay-to-win game. The system is fair and honest about what it offers.It's not a "bad game". It simply fails to hold any charm or provide a different experience than any other game of the same genre.The final veredict is: Not worth the time and effort....Unless you are a die hard fan of the franchise, or you had some very bad experiences with WOW, I doubt that you'll find anything in this game that is worth your time and money.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2012
												buggy, boring and repetitive quests. When you play the Lord of the Rings Online you will be presented with ALOT of fetch quest (fetch 5 flowers, slay this overpowered boss to collect his ring, travel to the opposite side of middle earth to talk to something and then return to collect a item you can't equip as you are not the right class, pick up some turtles, fetch more flowers, slay another overpowered boss) And the fact that it says "Free-to-Play" is a joke as once you hit level 30 (a total of 95 levels currently)there is nothing to do unless you purchase a region to have something to do, I understand that the game is "free" and the developers who worked hard on this need some income, but i feel that the term free-to-play meanings that players can slowly reach max level without having to open a wallet and should only purchase items to advance much quicker or unlock things that are rare and powerful not to continue the game that last only 10 levels. and that without other people to play with, some quest feel as they are impossible.If you are looking for a new game to play without feeling the need to open up your wallet to continue playing, avoid this as it is very boring, repetitive and not satisfing to play.But however i know some people who love this game and wouldn't like what i wrote so if you really want to play this, download it, my review is only a warning.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												This game used to be fantastic. That is, when people actually played it. Somewhere down the road this title decided it would be a fun idea to convert to a free-to-play game. "That's awesome!", however, wasn't the reply the producers got from their players who mostly just quit the game to go buy another franchise. The reason for this is that the devs took ideas from asian-grinders and everybody knows that doesn't work in the western world: players suddenly found themselves spending money for ingame items and somewhere between buying costumes and purchasing quest-packs forcefully to continue with progression they thought "this is simply wrong". Nobody wants to pay a dime for a dying old game.

												Yikes.  Perhaps I was too late to the party here, but this game looks and plays very poorly.  Again, perhaps this game was reviewed more favorably due to its relative quality at the time of release, but it's still almost impossible to recommend this with a straight face. This is kind of hard to say as a die-hard LotR fan, but take a pass on this clunker and save up your greenbacks for Middle Earth: Shadows of Mordor.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												Who doesnt like Lord of the Rings ? But to lie to the public. Let's define Free to Play shall we.You're allowed to log in and kill wolves. Leveling up takes ages.You can earn a couple of turbine points, but you can't really buy anything with them.If you're not VIP well why even bother.Instead of going into the lore more, you spend your time browsing the shop for stuff you wish you had. I dont mind paying sometimes but bloody hell... TOO EXPENSIVE.The combat interface is dull after couple of hours playing. All in all if you're a LOTR fanatic, you are better off watching the movies again and dreaming your part of it in your sleep rather than playing this game now.FYI: I had an non-steam account for it before and i just went back into it. And I want OUT. And good lord going from one quest to another takes like freakin forever.In short, F2P till level 30 then well got a million dollars ? Booooring. Too limited. Cheers.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Lord of the Rings Online is one of those F2P MMORPG's that seemed like a good idea at first. You get some sense of nostalgia when looking through all the different races and some of the classes. Because the classes have cameo's to the popular characters in the books/movies, but when in actual gameplay, they don't seem to do much at all.During my time playing, I was able to use the champion class, the ranger class, and the thief class. I apologise for getting most of those names wrong, it's been a while.The champion class screams at people, very entertaining, the ranger class can't kite well, and the thief class can't steal things.In short, the game is fun enough to try, and to those who have played any other type of MMO, especially the F2P MMO's they all fall into the same kind of gameplay.I won't tell you to stay away from this game, but I also don't recommend it.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												My main focus of play is their unique PvP system.  Based on my observation of the game I have found that game can be fun, but it is currently in bad shape when it comes to game balance in PvP.  Many features which were upgraded when level cap was increased were not fixed or upgraded on the Monster side of game (ex. health regneration, passive crit bonues, damage).  This means that currently there is a heavy imbalance in favor of the Free people characters.  The primary reason is that while release was properly implemented for teh Free people side, the monster part (which is important for PvP side) was mostly ignored during expansions releases.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												Lets see, The download wasn't that bad... but there was a second download within the game that doubled the original download time in total. The gameplay is more dull than World of Wacraft. The story is meh, if you're not a huge fanboy of Lord of the Rings. Art and detail is REALLY bad. There are two classes you have to pay for. If this game didn't take an hour and a half to download i would have thought this was a really well made browser game made by indie developers, but no this was made by a real company and published by Warner Bros. MEtacritic gave this game 86.... Planet side 2 (another free MMO) got 84, no, no... Bad call to action at the start. And last the layout for everything is just disgusting.The game was FREE TO PLAY. There is background to the Lord of the Rings but you wouldn't care at all if you didn't read every book and played every game. It tried to be like World of Warcraft or Guild Wars 2... but fell short.If you have a few hours try downloading the game and watch the numbers slowly rise from 0 to 10,000. This is just for the fan boy die hards. Anyone else stay clear.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Let's see here....1st of all made a character; an elven mage. Tried to customise him, but they all look the same.2nd thing I did, played the combat tutorial; classic MMO throw numbers at baddie and he throws them back; smaller numbers mean dead.Next I dragged myself through some gray corridors until some horribly voiced acted guy was all like; "oh no's! We're under attack :O"GUST OF WIND!!!! Most OP spell in the game!!! Just kidding it does nothing, you litterally throw glitter & it does nothing; the best spell I had was summon Dovahbear to fight for me. There's no penalty like mana to summon and he never died once. Hits waaaay harder than I ever could. Nice to know a wild animal can fill my place here.Met up with my buddy Noble. We ♥♥♥♥ed around with the relative system whilst the NPC's were yelling exposition at us. Nice to know he can be my mother, daughter and cousin all at the same time. Thanks game!Shopping happened.Me and Noble tried to go do a dungeon. A dwarven cemetary to be exact. It would be nice if we could go inside though. It's not too important to your dungeon ya know. Being able to use it.... oh well! Dovahbear's swimming animation is waaay more entertaining than the gameplay ever will be.I decided to follow Dovahbear off of a bridge. I got stuck in a watery hole. Still; seeing a bear doing doggy paddle is all the entertaining I need.Eventually I died. Probably starved to death. Maybe I killed myself. We will never know.I respawned in ring surrounded by wolves. Casted some gust of wind here and let my bear companion deal with the rest.My poor elven mage got so bored he hung himself. At least I hope he did. His fabulous ability to throw glitter at people with gust of wind didn't really help open that door the dungeon.Then everything went white. Then black. Then blue. That's either what happens when you die or when the game crashes. I'll never know because McAffee had the biggest temper tantrum with this game ever and purged my entire steam library.In conclusion; get this lose every other game. You can only play this game...Forever!!!!!!

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												As someone who frequents the f2p section of Steam I can say I was fairly dissapointed with this game. I confess right off the bat that I have been spoiled by other f2p mmo's particularly regarding voice acting (there is none in this game). I also need to make clear that while I enjoy the franchise I'm not the most well versed in the lore of the Lord of the Rings universe, and perhaps that's why I couldn't get inot the game. I found the game to feel similar to the later Elder Scrolls Online, the game feels like a generic fantasy mmorpg with a coat of lotr paint on it. Combat is your typical hotkey button mashing you've seen plenty of times before. The graphics are marginal, although the game isn't too recent so I'd say take it with a grain of salt. I didn't play for long before this game bored me to the point of asking the dreaded "why should I care?" Another point to give to the game is that I didn't find any pay to win (though once again I didn't play for too long). You might enjoy this game if you're really into the LotR world and lore, or if you have a group to role through the game with. If you're not very familiar with the universe and don't have anyone to play with I'd reccomend giving it a try as it is free, but I'm not sure you'll find too much enjoyment as there are much better mmorpg's that are also free.

number of helpful: 2 of 10 people (20%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												I don't know what to say.It is strange.I played more than 1000 hours on LOTRO (!) and I wouldn't recomand this game in any situation.I can see two situations right now : 1 :  you are a fan of Tolkien's world or of the films. This game is not for you. If you are a fan of Tolkien's world, the team tried to speak to you by adding names and histories that are from the background of Tolkien's work. Some homages, some references. That's kind of them. But it doesn't repair the damages that can be done by the simplist gameplay and the money motivations. If some (not even all, just one of two) of Peter Jackson's choices just bothered you, then forget this game : it is full of it. And the whole game encourage gamers to disrespect the canon. Lot of ignorants in there, in this domain anyhow. You'll find that this is lords of the rings for dummies, that people in there prefer Dungeons and Dragons than The Silmarillion. That's fine, but you must understand that. If you search for a strong passionate community, you'll be disapointed. You'll find some like yourselves, but you'll be all drowned in all the casual gaming and mainstream ideology.If you loved the films, you'll find that all what is in those films is not respected also. The adventure feeling isn't there, the characters are used as pretext, the missions have no depth. The action is inexistant. It is more like a World of Warcraft feeling. And This leads me to my second situation : 2 : you don't care about Tolkien's work. That's fine, I don't care about a lot of things too. But if this is the case, why LOTRO ? The same team developped a more suitable game : Neverwinter. Works well, same features, same feeling, not Tolkien's world and I am forced to say : it is better. Because when the team tries sometimes to stick to an adventure (The lord of the Rings) without achieving it, they force themselves to limit their imagination and the result is mediocre. When in Neverwinter, the have a clean slate and full of ideas.So here is my conclusion. I understand that it will not be loved by the LOTRO community but honestly, I don't care. I have felt what it is to be drawn in a game like this : you feel that you have to do all the daily missions, the events, the things, the stufs... and you forget why you do it. Then, one day, you wake up and you just ask yourself : wait... That's not what I was looking for". Sometimes, this wake up call is later for others, and when you are still in the process, you just don't want to hear anything like what I said, but the thing is : it is true.One big positive point though : the game has good graphics. Well, they are archaics, but the managed to do great things with it. The Shire is beautiful and peaceful, Imladris is has magic in the air, and good atmosphere. I just took more screenshots in this game than in all other games I have. The only thing is : while you are wandering on those great scenary, you bump into ugly things and it breaks the moment. But for contemplation moments, it is ok. It is great, even.I (or the road) could go on and on, I could speak about the whole gameplay driven by microtransactions and the fact that they gave a lot of things to the gamers sinces they pay for it, the fact that everything has no more coherence because of that, the fact that when they can choose to tweak a gameplay feature, they never choose logic and coherence, but always what could leat to more player buying, but that's propper to a lot of MMO and if you like MMO, you'll find those stuffs normal.So I will stop this long review here, that I tried honest and usefull.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												This game took forever to download and after having several difficulties and multiple hours wasted even trying to get it onto my computer, I was dismayed to find that the skin tones for player characters was very, very limited. As a black person and lover of high fantasy it is noteably very hard to find representation within shows, movies, etc that show such time periods, but often I have found that in MMO's or games that have at least some degree of character customization that allow darker skintones. Literally, the lightest I was able to go was a slightly darker tan. This turned me off from the game enough to delete it off of my computer completely, damn the hours I had wasted trying to play it in the first place. This kind of disappointment is unfortunately very common, but other games have included darker skintones and been able to hold much more vast audiences. LOTRO, please take notes from other games - Neverwinter, STO, Dragon Age, pratically anything else where you can customize yourself.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

content:
Posted: March 13
												I really want to like this game. In fact, there is a lot to like. The graphics are nice for something as old as this. The storytelling is great. The combat feels smooth. The soundtrack is good. Unfortunately, there is A LOT of bad too. The game has a focus on group content and yet doesn't really offer many ways to get a group together other than spamming global chat hoping to find people. The group finder tool simple doesn't work. And even when it does it's only for dungeons, not open-world non-soloable quest and definately not for story quests.  And that's the real kicker for me. The game's story has quests that you HAVE to group in order to compete.  There just isn't enough hand-holding, help getting there, direction, or other players to help a new player move along.

number of helpful: 2 of 11 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Let me detail to you my first hour or so of LOTRO gameplay.Created a Character. That was pretty cool acctually, Nice details, good naming system... nice.Spawned. It all goes to hell. Hobbit tells me to rescue some chums. I promptly rescue them. Suddenly, an enemy appears! A ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Black Rider Animation! End cutscene. Another enemy. I click on said enemy. I wait. My character uses his baseball bat, sorry, sword, to hack the man to the ground. I squint: seeing a bar at the bottom of my screen, I realize I can change HOW my character whacks at enemies by clicking on one of the tiny options presented there. I try one on the next enemy, who looks exactly the same as the first. Now, my character, a human ranger guy, swings at the Bad'un from the LEFT. I cackle with excitement. I never knew one could make a videogame character swing from the LEFT before! I'm in the world. I think for a moment: I need an eyetest. But of course, I forgot, this IS a fantasy world, everything is SUPPOSED to be horribly distorted! I walk towards this giant arrow thing on my screen. Sorry, I click on the ground and my character walks there. I stop for a second... Why is my character twitching? Why does it take so long for my character to respond to my commands? Oh, wait, despite my posession of High Speed Internet and a computer that would eat this game for lunch, LOTRO is laggy as hell. I forgot. Not that I play large Planetside 2 battles with no lag or anything. I click on this wierd trashbag-clothed guy and he tells me that, for a reward (that I could also buy in the LOTRO player store for real money) I should go out and kill things. I go out and, at about 5-10 fps, click on various bunny-sized creatures and watch my character hack them to death. Strangely enough, they don't move when my Char hits them, or react at all for that matter, but, for some reason, numbers keep flying out of their heads. I'll have to ask about that on the forums. Repeat. Reward.Repeat. (x999999999)Eventually, I am told to run off to some templ-y thing to kill more bunny-wolves. I promptly do so, and slay my way to the top of the temple, leaving a mound of wolves behind me, to get to a platform. Suddenly, there is a burst of flame, and an evil-looking man appears, holding a staff! He cackles widly, and, in a strangely American-sounding accent, tells me I am doomed. I grin with anticipation. Finnally! A fight worth my hard-won ability to swing from the left! I walk across the room and click on him, heart humming with the rythms of battle...I swing....He dies. A message pops up: "return to Quest Giver for reward." I stare at my screen, schocked. Still dazed, I exit the game and power down my computer. Eyes wide, I stumble to an adjacent room, where I collapse on the couch, twitching. After nearly an hour I awaken from what could only have been some sort of mental shut down. My first words are : "Someone should be executed for selling this trash." Do NOT get hyped because it's got a supposedly HUGE world. There's loading screens between every miniscule area. Play at your own risk.

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												Okay, I want to preface my review by saying that I love The Lord of the Rings and just about everything involving Middle-Earth.But, that said, I find myself questioning why I downloaded this game.I can hear it now, the people clamoring to tell me that I just need to give it chance.  However, that won't be happening, and for one good reason: the game does not work on my computer.A bit of information about my computer, since I know it is highly important to the working of the game:-Windows 8.1-AMD A8 2Ghz Processor-4 GB RAMThis would seem to be enough to play the game.  This is certainly enough to play a game that is arguably more taxing, namely Star Trek Online, which runs smoothly with only a few hiccoughs when my Internet connection slows.Now, for my review of the game.*Gameplay: 0/10*The Lord of the Rings Online, unlike Star Trek Online, does not run smoothly.  In fact, it barely runs at all.  After nearly three hours of downloading the game, I open it to discover another five hours of updates before I can play the game.  Once I open the game, I stare at a black screen for five minutes, waiting for something to happen.  Then, I am introduced to a cinematic cutscene with audio that is jerky and lags.  The video runs slowly, and I sit through another ten minutes of this.  I reach the character creation screen, and I finally have the game run smoothly.  There are no problems here.My character created, I enter Middle-Earth, and then I walk away from my computer to take care of some pressing issues.  I come back just as the the load screen disappears and my character shows up in a small room with only one other person present, Elrond.  Just an FYI, I created an Elf Hunter.  It is a level 1, since this was about as far as I got in the game.  I try to approach the wise Elder, only to learn that my actions have a serious lag time of five seconds.  Anyone who plays a MMORPG can tell you that even one second can be the difference between surviving a battle and dying horribly at the end of a goblin spear.  But I persevere.For another ten minutes, which is how long it takes me to reach the first door portal in the game.  I step through, and the game crashes.  Hard.  As in, I barely managed to get the Task Manager to open in order to End the game.*Graphics: 6.5/10*The graphics are not amazing, but they aren't terrible.  I really didn't get enough play time to determine much, but from what I did see, they earned an average score.*Story: N/A*I only played for a short time before I was done, so I can't even begin to guess what the story is about.  I caught something about a Dwarf and some artifact that belonged to some wraith or something... yeah, I've got no clue.*Player Interactions: N/A*With this being an MMORPG, or so I've heard, there should be player interaction at some point.  I never saw it, for the sole reason that I never got out of the tutorial.*Final Verdict: 0.5/10*tl;dr - I honestly want to play this game, but as it currently stands, I never will unless I find someone in the real world who has it and will deign to let me play for a couple of hours.

												So basically I've downloaded this game in hopes that It will be good.. I was kinda dissapointed. I just hope this game gets better overtime and one day It will be as good as all the other MMORPG's out there (except AION).

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												It's really boring. I've played about an hour now and decided to give up. You can't even play a real spellcaster without paying money. Right there that's a major difference from Neverwinter, a game that for some reason has a lower review level on here. Yes, Neverwinter is very repetitive but at least the graphics are better and the combat is challenging even for spellcasters. I'm not an expert on MMORPG's but I know what's fun to play and what isn't, and this isn't. Some of the positive reviews say stuff like "It's fun if you like exploring", "It's fun if you play with friends". It does have a huge map. But if the combat system is simply right-click and sit back, that's really outdated; I'd rather play Summoner I and II than this. And the spells for a class like loremaster are pretty lame. I don't understand the point of the game's development. Is it simply to build a huge world and then have crappy combat? I mean, what is the goal of the game for fun? Isn't an RPG supposed to be about specifically chosen character progression (by you, not the computer) in skills and levels, and then good melee and spell choices? Without those fundamental RPG attributes in a game, an RPG like this one just plain sucks, there is no getting around it.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												This has to be one of the worst MMOS I've ever played. The controls are clunky, the world is dead and doesn't encourage exploration (map areas are locked for too long and fast travelling doesn't work) the storyline is boring, cliched and vague, the leveling is broken, and the menus are confusing in this poor rendition of Middle Earth.I don't have high expectations for MMOS, but this one is painful to play and I'm sure has Tolkien rolling around in his grave.It may have been fun to play back when it was first released, but it is dry and uninspiring now.That being said, it is fun to play if you feel like playing a terrible MMO with your friends for the kicks.

number of helpful: 7 of 25 people (28%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28
												I tried to give this game a fair chance, but there are a couple of problems with it that make it impossible for me to recommend it.1 - It claims to be Free To Play, but in the end it boils down to Pay To Win (aka Feemium). Anything worth having is on the LOTRO store for prices that make it impossible to get without paying real-world cash for the coins.2 - This game is not for us who live in places where you still have to pay per megabyte of data, there are large "updates" every time the launcher starts. Looking at what is updating, I have to ask myself if I really need to be paying for different language loading screens.3 - Now it's broken. The latest update seems to have broken my copy (at least), which probably means I'd have to delete the game files and re-download it if I wanted to play further (see point 2).4 - I haven't really been paying much attention to world chat, but once or twice I noticed comments like "if you don't want to be in a fellowship go find a single player game" and "if you want to quest alone go find a single player game". A community that tells players to go away because they want to play a game in their own way is in trouble and heading toward becoming toxic.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												The beginning of the game is ok due to the cinematic gameplay you are involved in but as you level up it takes on the form of any other MMO. If you like questing in MMOs in general then you have the normal grindy leveling situation. I am not sure about endgame stuff  because I never have the time nor attitude to do that so I have no opinion. Plus, most endgamers won't even give me the time of day since I have bad gear and not very good on the keypad in Raids. Kind of stinks since at one time I loved MMOs and wanted to do end game stuff when it is hard not when they dumb stuff down for pug groups. The graphics are dated now although the game still looks "good" but definately looks older than it is. The game is worth trying to see if it is your cup of tea. I won't rate it since most people who like MMOs will try them out to see if they like them. It is F2P now anyhow and I think you have to buy level packs to move past a certain point but that make be changed now. I have played the game more than 8 hours before I installed it on Steam. I made it to the 30s before I stopped playing on another account. If you like LOTR lore you will like playing the game other than that try it out past level 20s.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Initial impressions:Ok, so far, severely disappointing. I see a lot of good reception for this game but have absolutely no clue where it comes from. The graphics look more like they are from 2006 rather than 2012 and still the game manages to lag every time a new thing appears on the horizon. The writing has been fairly simple so far and the quests have been about collecting or killing an x number of something. The controls are actually inferior to standard MMO controls. Whatever happened to clicking on the enemy and your character running up and attacking automatically? Was that too advanced so that we had to go back to manually running to targets and getting smacked in the back because we ran a bit too far and clipped through the enemy, as your character won't attack unless he is facing the enemy? It's not like the old control system is being traded for advanced fighting techniques (like in Elder Scrolls) since the rest of the cotnrols is still just about clicking on enemies and pushing hotkeys. The game isn't terrible. I did notice that the world seems to be gigantic, which is nice, and everything seems to be functional, but so far LOTRO it's just a standard barebones MMO. If that is what I'm in for then I might as well go back to playing Lineage II from 2003. I keep pushing through to see if it gets more interesting or special later, but so far...no.CORRECTION: sorry, indeed the game turned out be from much earlier, so I take that part back, but as for the other stuff, I realised that I just don't have the time to wait a while and see if things get better. Who does? Besides the job and studies, there are so many other games, many co-op or mmo. Maybe that was not as applicable 10 years ago, but now...man.

number of helpful: 3 of 20 people (15%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22
												A 'could have been great' game, The Lord of the Rings Online™ is what I would call a Mega-MMORPG, consisting of a HUGE world for players to delve into and explore. The graphics don't disappoint either-Some of the best graphics in any MMORPG can be seen in The Lord of the Rings Online™. In addition to this, there is plenty of customization and stuff to do for new and veteran players alike for each of their characters. Unfortunately, this is where the high-points of this once-proud game taper off. Even completely new players will soon realize this game will most likely be a life-long effort if reaching Max Level is their primary goal. In addition to this, the pay-to-win factor is high here, with plenty of 'services' tailored for players who have real money to spend...Like the Riding Skill. And it only gets worse from there...Once a player achieves Level 20-25-ish, the monsters become tougher and more aggressive, and the quests only become harder. Of special note here are the prerequisites for completing certain quests. You may have to carry a certain item (Such as a bucket of water) from one location to another, which becomes a tedious task as you are unable to battle monster mobs and you are likely to encounter at least one mob! In addition to this, there are at least a few instances of repetitive monsters-I.E. Boars!! The grinding quickly becomes more apparent and certain sounds or noises in the game could be a bother to players with auditory sensitivity. Yes, they give out free presents every day a player logs in, but usually, they end up tossed away as useless junk items. The one and only time I played, I also noticed a lack of any sort of active community. And seeing as how this was WAY back in 2013-2014, I wouldn't wanna return to this game to see how much it has decayed since then.Pros...Ability to select a classNice customization options for your characterFairly easy tutorialAwesome graphicsGood selection of items/weapons/armor/spellsAbility to purchase and ride a horse (And later a War Steed)Ability to purchase and live in a fairly small houseMany quests are fairly easy to doYou can create more than one character per accountWell-Done story-line and voice actingCons...The main way of gaining XP is through completion of questsThere are several quests requiring a party or 'fellowship'The riding skill must be purchased with real money to be able to ride a horseAcquiring a War Steed requires the player to be Level 75The game could potentially download and run slower on PC's with lesser graphics drivers and RAMMuch of your efforts will consist of long-distance traveling...Even while riding on horseback!Some items/weapons/armor/spells can only be used by certain classesSpeaking of classes, you have to pay to play as one of themIt's rather easy to get killed in this game if you're not careful...Music doesn't appeal to me/Doesn't sound very goodCertain sound effects are capable of making my ears bleed!...Figuratively of courseGaining levels beyond Levels 20 to 25 requires MUCH more time and effort!Final Score-3 Stars-Bad!

												well to be honest i have only played this game for 10 minutes. before i continue, this is my OPINION. if you disagree because you played it more than 10 minutes than don't take what i am going to say personally and don't make a discussion out of it. i have better things to do ;)people may find it unappropiate because i just played it for such a short time, but i just wanna share my thougts about those 10 minutes. first i wanna talk about the mood/atmosphere of the game (sorry if i said it wrong). i am talking about the feeling of the game. when i saw the intro, i found it a bit cheesy. wich is fine for the genre. but when the intro ended and i came to the menu, the whole lotr fibe was gone for me. too much happiness, too much (sorry to say this) WOW rip off and too less lotr. wich brings me to the graphics: the game looks too simple. the models, the detaills on models, etc. for a game that is still played today, dissapoints me. especially when i had to download 18 gigs and i get something that looks like 400 mb. its 2017, at least scale the models of the 5 classes, so that the body doesn't look like someone who has been on stretched on a rack or who has been put in a small cage for months. the game looks like the concept is more important than actually make it perfect. people want lotr, they get an everyday mmorpg that rips off mechanics from different mmos and put in hobbits and dwarfs to make it lotr. this brings me to details. oh god the details.... like: almost no detaills what so ever. too less blood if you compare it to any other lotr movie, game or even the book. no lotr details in buildings, characters or gameplay. maybe further in game in some quests maybe, but i don't wanna find out anymore. now the gameplay. the gameplay is so much ripped off i could play any other game. why play lotr online, while you can play any other mmorpg wich is exactly the same but better? just because it is lotr? give me a break.looking around, walking and engaging fights is really really sloppy. fighting goes auto, wich looks very glitchy and unsynchronized. i chose the hunter, and he kept changing from daggers to bow like he was some kind of magician. it looked REALLY bad. i could complain more, but ive already complaint more about the game then the time i spent playing it. I just want to say it is the worst game i have tried out in years. Conclusion: don't play this game. this is not what you want in a lord of the rings game. go play any lotr game that is not this one to actually feel you are busy with lotr instead of playing a game that is like any other game, but worse and just names its game, characters and items after the legendary stories of JRR Tolkien just to gain players.it is NOT worth ANYTHING, even the time to download.again: MY OPINION.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												This is surely the most beautiful and in every way perfect MMORPG. Playing this won't be boring even after thousands of hours played. Of course there are awesome quests, but also very nice crafting system, instances, housing and others. The most powerful attribute of this game is definitely world of beautiful environments, places you may know from movies and books, but also large amount of new places, places that will make♥♥♥♥♥♥yourself of their darkness. It's awesome game indeed, but still there is one bad thing - the higher your level is, the more awesome the game is, so there are some little boring parts in the introduction, especially if you play as a hobbit. Thankgod this part is short and it's followed by thrilling story and side quests, hobbies and stuff, like you've never seen. Maybe it can get boring again if you'll be low leveled and you'll need to level up with no quests left, but quest packs and expansions can fix it, and they are not expensive at all, you can even buy them for game cash, not real money. Well, this game is my first love, i recommend it to all of you!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 10, 2012
												short version: the game is authentic to the middle earth mythos and has tremendous detail.it is easy to learn with good tutorials and the classes and races feel unique in how they play.a halfling burgler [bilbo baggens is a burgler class character] is different than a human burgler.rangers are quite different from lore masters.and i love it.longer version:i started playing the game long before it was on steam.i bought the game when it was REQUIRED to pay a monthly subscription fee for access to the game.i have seen the game expand and grow to what it is now.i approve.if you don't know the mythology that was built around middle earth, this is a great game and has many different ways to play.you can play casual or intense and you will find a community that is the most helpful and friendly of any multiplayer online game i have seen, and i have been playing online games since the mid '90's when they were all text games.the game is primarily "co-operative" player mode where you see and know and interact with many other players.there is PVP where you can take your characters from the co-operative world and have fun at PVP and return to the co-operative part of the game with the treasures and experience earned in the PVP area.you can be a burgler. a traveling mistral ,a warrior, or a maker of jewelry and pies.oh yes and a spell caster also.you can probably find some aspect of the game that appeals to your "style".if you know about middle earth you will be pleased to see that the team that developed, and is still developing this game are also familiar with the stories and have taken great care to be true to the original concept put forth in the books years ago.one example of this would be walking past a stone troll standing on a hill in the middle of a swamp in a certain area, and you knowing the story behind why it is there. no sign posted with the story, no explanation offered, but if you have read the story you know why it is there.and many other things like the last homely house and you get to meet tom bombadill at his house.when or if you meet bilbo baggins, elron, strider or gandalf it is done in a believable way that does not break or even stretch the known original story lines from the books.and being free to play with micro-transactions does not mean "pay to win" in this game.the ability to earn turbine points from actions in the game [turbine points are what you pay real world cash for]  makes this game different than other free to play games that i have seen, even among those other games with ways to earn points in the game.so you can learn skills and do deeds that are supporting of the "middle earth mythos" and be rewarded with points that can otherwise be bought.points in the game are earned mostly for working along lines that advance or support the "feel" of middle earth.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												First of all this is one of the better WoW copys... Not an exact copy, but hey it's one of those that is very similar is it not?.. But in a good way. What I like about Lotro is unlike WoW the soloing feels much more worthwhile,, example questing, deeds, proffs, etc. Not as many A hole players in the community (compared to WoW, but you're still bound to run into some somewhere) Also like that you can do some instances solo, and that there's a whole main story chain quest throughout the game comprised of instances at certain points. Great lore, well working game engine and mechanics imo, and decent graphics for what it is. Wouldn't regret giving it a shot, but I myself went ahead and bought the sub cause I hate being limited to 30 lvls, but you can still buy the game zone by zone.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Surprisingly, really ♥♥♥♥ing good.  I was expecting another hack off MMORPG, but LOTRO has a huge number of features thta arguably make it the best F2P MMORPG on the market right now.First off, it's filed with pre-established lore.  An excellent job was done in making the player feel inside the LotR universe, and it shows that the develops didn't have to scrounge around for source materialAkin to early WoW, you're not a special snowflake.  You're just another player in this vast world; there are wars going on that you are only a soldier in, you can make small differences here and there but as a whole the world doesn't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about you.  And this is a WONDERFUL MMORPG CONCEPT.  It contributes heavily to the immersion, and makes the game as a whole more compelling to play.The unique skill and trait trees.  Every game ♥♥♥♥ing has these, but forcing the player to earn the right to use traits or improved skills, even if most of them are just kill 9000 boars and gather kobold candles, gives meaning to the word 'skills'.  Your character worked to improve themselves, and it is reflected in their abilities.  These aren't things that just come along easily while leveling: it takes a large amount of game time to master skills and traits, even with dedicated grinding.  Your character is reflecting the effort and time put into the game, and that in of itself is a fantastic concept.Lastly I just want to mention one feature that really put this game into the forefront of my mind.  Fall damage.  Most MMORPGs just adopt the WoW %health based fall damage, but this is one area where LOTRO exceeds everything else on the market.  Falling say a story or two doesn't damage your health.  Falling several stories or off a small cliff gives you an injury, which reduces movespeed immensely, removes any capabilities for dodging or negating damage, and lasts for 30 seconds.  Rather than punishing the player by forces them to do a spawn run or what have you when they attempt to speed up their travel by skipping flights of stairs, LOTRO realistically reduces the movespeed of the player by "breaking their leg", meaning that you can jump if you want to, but it is probably faster to walk down the stairs.  But keeping in tandem with the realism, if you jump off a mountain or fall off a building, you are going to die.  However it has to be an extreme height, so there is no fear of dying from simple stair skipping, and it actually causes fear if you come to close to a cliff's edge or accidentally slip off of a roof.All in all, a solid 9/10, easily the best Free-to-play MMORPG on the market.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												The hours that Steam has logged as me playing this game do not equal the amount of hours I have put into this game.  This is through no fault of Steam, I started playing LotRO around 3.5 years ago, and was not using Steam for part of that, and I can tell you that my hour count probably is closer to 1,000.  That should be a good indicator of what I think of this game.If that is not enough, then let me simply go off on a paragraph or two of love for this game.I have tried other F2P MMOs out there, jumping here and there, but none of them really did it for me.  They were all missing something, or some things, and I couldn't quite put my finger on it.  Then, one winter break, my brother sent me an IM, telling me we should give it a go, it looked like fun.  Again, that was 3.5 years ago.  I haven't looked back, and I will be forever grateful to him for introducing me to this game.For starters, the game is fairly true to its word, it is Free to Play.  There are many players who have gone through the entire game content, buying quest packs, expansions, and fun little extras without paying a cent in real money.  The game allows players oppertunities to "earn" turbine points, the buyable currency, through the completion of "deeds," little meta quests.  In order to look "cool" within the game, one only needs to complete a few skirmishes, or take a browse through the auction house to aquire neat looking gear.  Want a horse?  No problem.  The player initially uses turbine points to buy the riding trait from the store, but upon the creation of your first character (perhaps even on each server, not simply first account character), you are granted 100 tp to buy this skill.  Afterwards, one can purchase nearly ever horse availible within the game using the in game currency of gold, silver, and copper.  Long story short, the game does not bar players from looking great, getting around as fast as their companions, and joining their companions in their adventures, simply because they don't want to shell out some cash.Secondly, the content is really nice.  Everyone has their least favorite areas (ugh, Lone Lands...), but the way the story plays out and takes you through zones is really fun!  Within the game, you are not riding alongside the Fellowship, but working in other parts of the world, because there are more things happening than just the discover of the One Ring.  The main story line (or Epic Quest, Book Quests, ect) is interesting and enthralling, and you will find yourself getting caught up in certain places, feeling for the characters you meet (the end of the Shadows of Angmar books is a doozy, watch your step!).  Along side the epic quests are side quests, like most games, which are equally interesting and often provide a deeper look into the lore of Middle Earth, and a closer look at the story of Lord of the Rings.But I think the most...wonderful, really, part of LotRO is how it looks.  It is perfect.  Visually stunning even in the early zones, and outragiously beautiful as you get to the most recently released areas, it is easy to simply spend time roaming around the fields of Bree, bundling up and sliding down an icy hill in Forochel, or poking around dark corners in Moria.  There are tiny details everywhere, and it all seems to be carefully considered and designed, and is a vision of Middle Earth that I am more than happy to adopt as my default.  There are so many hidden nooks and crannies, little scenes, and secrets to find, and it's well worth it to just take a day to wander and forget about questing.I think, in the end, that's what really keeps me coming back to LotRO.  It's a game that has a solid amount of everything.  Exploration, crafting, roleplay, raiding.  The community is wonderful, I've made so many friends, and I cannot recommend this game highly enough.If you have any more questions, or want to see screenshots from the game, head over to http://elfwithacamera.tumblr.com.  I hope to see you in Middle Earth!
