content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Best MMO I have ever played. World is fantastic, even just the F2P. Story is interesting and well told and everything is very close to Tolkein's works. The game is never impossible but also has a good level of challenge and will keep you occupied for hours. However, the shining part of this game is the business model. Downloading it gets you the whole world (until Western Rohan) to explore and the main quest (again until Western Rohan), though you are unable to access any misc quests after the first four areas (Ered Luin, The Shire, Bree-land and the Lone-Lands). Further questing requires quest packs, however these can be bought using money OR Turbine Points, which can be earned in game and, in fact, many quest packs have the potential to return the investment with just 2/3 characters going through it, which, with many, will be irresistable. Personally I loved Evendim, which is worth roughly £6, or 595 Turbine Points. It kept me hooked for many hours, was fantastic for levelling and returned about 100TP of my investment in just one day. I got it with the Eriador bundle which includes Evendim, North Downs, Forochel, Trollshaws, Angmar, Eregion, Enedwaith and Misty Mountains and costs 3995 TPs (about £30 worth) and gives a huge game world which feels to be at least three times bigger than Skyrim. The combat is standard MMO fare, quickslots and auto-attack, but is fairly well-balanced with improvements planned in the next couple of updates.I only have two major flaws with the game. Firstly, the download time the SECOND time you load it up is ridiculously long for some and only takes a couple of minutes for some. My other flaw is some store items (like the Riding Skill) will slow progress if you want all QPs and Expansion packs using earned in-game points. To get about some of the later, and larger, areas, you will NEED a mount. However, it costs 95TPs to get the riding skill for each character. There are also a few dubious paywalls, or at least they seem that at first, but these are minor. For example, the quild access packs take a while to show much benefit, though later on do give some very good bonuses: making and improving your own legendary item which allows you to not rely on randomised drops and relics. However, every MMO needs consistent income, especially when more expansions and QPs are set to come (Gondor and Mordor all planned for the coming couple of years). The community is also the most helpful I have ever encountered. Overall I would give this a 9/10, the game being a little out of date graphics wise, but in terms of story, gameplay and the world itself, this is perhaps the best MMO I've ever had the pleasure of stumbling across.

												YES ! YES ! YES ! The Lord of the Rings Online.This is my game.To start off,I have hundreds of hours in the game though i have very few on steam because i recently started playing it here.LotRO is a one-of-a-kind game.It's not your common Pay-to-win MMORPG.As a Free-to-play player I can confirm this.In my hundreds of hours in the game not once did i have to pay for something which i can buy with the points i've won by playing the game.The market is amazingly made.There are currently 9 classes (7 available for F2P players and 2 purchasable through the store).The quests vary so you can enjoy the game even if you are playing it solo.There are tons of instances,raids and skirmishes for you to do.The game offers an incredible Co-operative experience and the end-game content is still developing.Pros: - Good class variety        - Racial differences (that sounded racist)        - Always updated endgame content        - Great variety of quests        - Turbine points can be earned without paying        - True to LOTR loreCons: - Grinding turbine points can get boring          - Intros are boring          - Graphics are sub-par  Verdict: 9/10 Outstanding Game Recommendation: Strongly recommended for Role-playing minded players and LOTR fans.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2013
												Entertaining casual MMORPG. Key features are a very well thought-out F2P system (you can subscribe and get it all, or pay as you go for each bit of content, something possible without spending any money if you're really dedicated), giant world, interesting classes and impressive level of adherence to the LOTR lore. The downside is that, due to the aforementioned adherence to the LOTR lore, a handful of things that make other MMOs fun aren't to be found here as they interfere with the lore. For instance, a large chunk of the world is rather plain looking, easy on the eyes with very little variety (in contrast, to, say, WoW), there are no fancy flying mounts or even fancy regular mounts, just a large variety of horses and some goats, and you can forget about super-duper-kill-all moves with flashy eye candy, because you won't find them in this game. Whether that's good or bad is ultimately up to you, however.The Steam download file size for this is ridiculously big, so I recommend you download it from the official site instead.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Absolutely fantastic considering this game is F2P and has no monthly or bi/tri-monthly subscription fee. This game has kept my amused for hours and has a huge map to explore and tons and tons of content to dive into. This is further enhanced by the links to J.R.R Tolkein's world, making the world feel more like home (Assuming you've read or watched the Lord of the Rings books or films) unlike other MMOs, such as World of Warcraft. The only areas in which this game is let-down is the early level co-op features. I never delved too far into these as I could never see where I could access them. I played with 3 or 4 other friends and we just ended going around and doing the same quests as each other as we never found a way to do raids with each other or do boss fights together etc. 8/10 - Overall, a great game and definitely worth downloading as it's free and offers at least 50 hours of quality gameplay, which can be doubled by purchasing new areas to delve into.

												Turbine have beautifully re-imagined Tolkien's classic.If you're a fan of Middle-Earth and want to immerse yourself in that world, this is the game for you.Despite being F2P it's certainly not P2W; it doesn't punish free players in the way other games do with many opportunities to gain premium currency for additional perks.If you like playing with a group, I would recommend playing with friends as starter areas of the game can feel and often are empty. content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Better than you'd think.  The graphics are mostly lacking, although they do support DirectX11 features.  It used to work fantastically in Wine, but the new launcher's broken support.  I love playing music in the game; it has some great instruments and player-music support.  Sometimes I login just to entertain people with music.  You can also play .abc files (a midi-like format that you can edit by hand), and even syncronize yourself with several other musicians to get a band of people playing different parts of the same song.  Best music system I've seen in any game, ever (although the actual background music of the game isn't particularly noteworthy (and no, it doesn't have songs from the lotr films))It also has one of the absolute best cosmetic systems of any MMO I've played, although dying isn't quite as in-depth as Guild Wars 2.  Overall, it's not mind-blowing, but it's a fun game to play from time to time.NOTE: I have many more hours than Steam thinks I do; I usually play the game on Linux in Wine, outside of Steam.

I love the Lotr series, and that was the main reason I decided to download this game.At first I was put off by the turbine point system, but when I realised that points could literally be earned, I decided to make it a personal 'goal' as such to complete as much as I could to expand my way through the game. It may feel daunting and like a grind fest but you get a feeling of accomplishment when you earn your way through a game. I've not come across a real issue with pay 2 win gear since there really isn't pay to win gear (especially since if there was you would simply need to earn the points to gain whatever is needed).More about the actual game:Imagine WoW. It plays very similar to that in terms of questing and PvE (Right click and hotkey). You have a few classes and 4 races to choose from, which is relatively extensive. Choose your hair, eyes, nose, lips etc, class and race, each race has certain limitations to classes (as expected) but not as limited as one might think. Once you've chosen those, you can choose where you're from, which each come with certain changes to hair colour (unless you want to change is again). Once you hit level 10 you can do monster play, which as you could imagine, lets you play as one of the monsters from the lotr series, initially you can only choose one to play as, but the turbine system allows you to play as more if you buy them.Work your way through the universe of lotr and see the world in your own perspective!Definitely reccomended to anyone who liked the lotr series. Gameplay: 10/10Character creation: 8/10 could be a little more in depth but a very sound system.Quest system: Pretty good, the usual really, talk to... or kill.... or gather...etc.Lore: Friggin' 11/10. Exceptional since it practically throws you into the mix of the lotr series, witness Gandalf stop Balrog in a dream, and be told that the fate of the free people will rest on your shoulders.Point system:5/10. Only ranked so low since it can feel like a drag, unless you're one of these grind fanatics that absolutely LOVE grinding in games. Completing deeds will reward you with turbine points, but not a vast amount, usually about 5-15 tp each time. An upside is that most deeds can be completed twice but with an added end value (example: slay 30 orcs > deed completed > 5 tp gained and title bestowed > slay 60 orcs > 10 tp added) and considering you get certain deeds each time you enter a new area, like Bree-land to the Shire, your deeds will change to the area specific deeds allowing you to gain more tp.I think I've covered everything, and gone on long enough.GET THIS GAME NOW![/b]

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												I will say there is nothing new or incredibly innovative about this game, but what it does it manages to do well and with a polish that is surprisingly addictive. I would recomend this to people who want to try a new MMO, especially since it is free. As far as the microtransactions go, it is really more of a problem for those who wish to try and max out their character. To the casual player, the annoyances are in having two locked classes and having difficulty with mounts, but both of these can be overcome by using the ingame achievement system to get enough points (for free) to purchase the relevant products. Quest packs (large scale ones that is) are generally too expensive to be worth the time it would take to earn the points to get them however.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Dose the idea of aiding in an epic quest line from behind the scenes grab your interest? Have you wondered what story book hero's do between the there chapters of the tale? If you, like myself, find you are an Emerson Gamer then here is an opportunity get yourself lost in the chapters of a masterpiece. I was turned on to this M.M.O. by my brother as a way to stay connected while he was in the service. Soon after the prelude we found ourselves adventuring to Bree & the inn called "The Prancing Pony", Selecting quests from the many faces that populate the land, & Riding horseback through "The Trollshaws" toward "The Mines of Moria". I found I can even choose how close to the story my 'toon' can live. You will find the many of the more technical points approached in Ammolds von Lichenstein's review which outlines the game  very well, yet not much attention was paid to the aspect of player vs. player. If you feel the need to test your skills in combat against other players you can challenge them to Duel or try your luck in Monster Mode. (I really enjoy Monster Mode) This solves the problem of assassination (P.C. Campers), brutal fights (P.K.ers), or deadly robberies (Trolls). An ideal choice especially if your new to M.M.O.s.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Lord of the Rings Online is a fantastic game that has fallen into a rut. Two or three expacs ago, the game could count itself among some of the best MMO's for pvp and raiding content. Since the Riders of Rohan release in 2012 in particular however, the endgame content has felt flimsy and uninspired. With the recent release of Helms Deep, the endgame content is virtually nonexistent ("Big Battles" which feel more like "Big Cluster F***s"). The lore, however, is ever present and I will continue to play the game due to its fantastic story arcs and beautiful landscapes. For the Tolkien nut, I'd strongly recommend this game. If you're looking for hardcore MMO content, take yourself elsewhere.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2013
												I have fond memories of this game from the old days.  It's an MMO that lets you wander about Eriador in Tolkien's Middle-Earth.  You can by a house in The Shire, ride a horse to Rivendell and hang out with Elrond, talk with Goldberry at the Withywindle, put up with Lobelia Sackville-Baggins...and that's what I love about it.  Levelling up, finding and crafting loot, trading and auctioning, grinding, all that's there, and pretty well done.  But the charm of this game is the attention to detail to Tolkien's world without relying on the movies for inspiration.  Unfortunately, since the game went free-to-play, a lot of the cool stuff now has to be purchased separately, even for people like me who already bought the game.

												I might be a little biased because I have been playing since beta, and I'm a lifetime subscriber, but this is the best MMO I have ever played. Hands down. And this is coming from someone who cut her teeth on Ultima Online, and was a founding member of WoW. It's one of the only MMORPGs that really plays up the RP. No one doesn't like RPing a Hobbit Farmer from the Shire that has a lucrative pipeweed crop to sell. And the whole single player aspect of the game holds up so well that you can RP a solo rogue and never talk to another person.Just try it out. It's free and the ftp is actually worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
													It's a ton of fun, and since it's not tied to the Peter Jackson LOTR, you get to see a different style of Middle Earth. The fact that you get to be any race in Middle Earth, and that they all have unique backstories for your character is pretty cool. The music and atmosphere is great, and the combat mechanic, while fairly unimaginative, works very well. THe community is big and most people are nice, helpful, and have an appreciation for the source material.	That being said, the fact that you have to pay to play for pretty much anything not related to the main story line past level 20 means that you will either have to fork over tons of cash, or just grind for hours and hours.	Overall, I have and will again recommend this game, but with a few warnings.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												This game has gone a long way. It might be a bit challenging to properly rate or recommend this game from the many expansions that have come out. This is definitely a game that you have to make the time and enjoy the journey. There isn't really any endgame or benefit in making it all the way to the end. If anything, playing a hobbit through The Shire would be the best experience for any fan of the Tolkien books. Much of the classes and beginning areas won't cost you anything. If you wish to venture a little further, maybe into Moria, you will have to put forth some dollar amount. As enjoyable as the landscape is to look at, the game runs into problems as you progress in the later levels. The system buildup in your character, the area you explore, and how smoothly the combat runs is a detriment. Optimization is lacking and you will run into long load times and sluggish behavior on even the lowest of settings. Some people may feel like the game isn't true to its source. I like to think that I have never felt more immersed.

The one thing i dislike is the time you have to spend to travel if you don't have a stead... BUT that is acceptable. I did not experience PvP yet, but the PvE is a bit too easy for me. The crafting system is awesome, plus the game does not try to get your money at every occasion, the game can be totally F2P if you want it, but still, you can get a VIP if you like your games less rough. The quests vary from boring "bring this, kill that" to epic multi-threaded adventures.This game is not a waste of time, and i rarely got upset by something.I recommend it dearly!

												I have been playing LotRO off and on for the last six years.  It's my "go-to" MMO.  If I start a new games and I am disappointed, I always patch LotRO and play it again for a few months.  The game is a little dated, compared to the new generation of graphics, but the world is still beautiful.  The storyline is closer to the books than the movies, which I really appreciate.  The player community is awesome.  There is very little trolling, gold-selling, etc.  The player base is extremely helpful.  As long as the servers stay up, I will be playing LotRO.

												It feels fantastic to walk in the world of Middle Earth. It's been my dream to fight alongside Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli, and with Lord of the Rings Online, that dream can come true. With some brilliant graphics, a wide range of characters, and a seemingly endless supply of quests, there's no doubt in LotRO being one of the best MMORPGs out there. It has a fantastic and friendly community, which you can interact with in Kinships, and team up with other players to battle enemies in fellowships.One of the things that I don't really approve of is the fact that you have to buy access to some region quests, which, for someone like me who doesn't really have money to spare, will frankly slow down your levelling to a complete stop, forcing you to end participation in the Epic Quest route. Maybe it could come to that some of the regions become free to play around in, because I'm kinda sick of being stuck at level 44.Overall 8.5/10, some areas need to be improved, but I'm frankly glad this game exists.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
													It's a ton of fun, and since it's not tied to the Peter Jackson LOTR, you get to see a different style of Middle Earth. The fact that you get to be any race in Middle Earth, and that they all have unique backstories for your character is pretty cool. The music and atmosphere is great, and the combat mechanic, while fairly unimaginative, works very well. THe community is big and most people are nice, helpful, and have an appreciation for the source material.	That being said, the fact that you have to pay to play for pretty much anything not related to the main story line past level 20 means that you will either have to fork over tons of cash, or just grind for hours and hours.	Overall, I have and will again recommend this game, but with a few warnings.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												This game has gone a long way. It might be a bit challenging to properly rate or recommend this game from the many expansions that have come out. This is definitely a game that you have to make the time and enjoy the journey. There isn't really any endgame or benefit in making it all the way to the end. If anything, playing a hobbit through The Shire would be the best experience for any fan of the Tolkien books. Much of the classes and beginning areas won't cost you anything. If you wish to venture a little further, maybe into Moria, you will have to put forth some dollar amount. As enjoyable as the landscape is to look at, the game runs into problems as you progress in the later levels. The system buildup in your character, the area you explore, and how smoothly the combat runs is a detriment. Optimization is lacking and you will run into long load times and sluggish behavior on even the lowest of settings. Some people may feel like the game isn't true to its source. I like to think that I have never felt more immersed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												I speak for those who can't or don't have time to pay for VIP (monthly-sub) and for you frugal troglodytes out there including myself. LOL.So far so good. Two potential concerns.. even VIPs don't get expansions as part of the deal. Buying all the expansions costs around $150. You start off with 45 bag slots which fills up really soon. Maxing out on your bags will cost about $64. You can purchase up to 12 additional +5 bag slots for a total of 60 more slots. 12 x 325 TP each = 3,900 or 4k. If 500 points is $8 then 4k will cost $64.Conclusion? So far, the expansions and bags will cost more than $200. This isn't arguable. I'm just stating facts.Yes, there are ways around piece-meal unlocks.. I heard a lot of people recommend buying a one-month sub. You can do that then buy the expansions on a piece-meal basis. The MMO's really polished. Classes are different but odd different if that makes sense.I wish the "one-time" Silver purchase would actually mean something compared to all of the above. So much for a F2P title, eh?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												For anyone who likes a good free-to-play game, and Lord of the Rings, will probably like it. Those who love LOTR and have read more than that: don't worry. The game is full of little details hinting towards the backstories, and are usually quite spot on. (Annatar's name is not exactly Annatar due to rights, but hey -better than nothing!) Also, though there is some content you have to buy, you can get "turbine points" by doing deeds (use a skill x amount of times), and so buy those contents without actually spending money. (Though some amounts are just huge and will take loads of grinding.)You can play as an Elf, a Hobbit, a Dwarf or as a Man, and they all have different starting points. Community is nice and friendly...most of the time. Yeah. Beautiful sceneries. Many events. Such fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												Very immersive game world that is filled with many points of interest for fans of Tolkien's lore, with the best community in any MMO i've played. Very fair F2P model with the riding skill being the only really necessary thing to unlock, plus there are several easy ways to earn Turbine Points (the game's store currency), through questing and deeds (acheivements). Graphics are slightly above the level of WoW and some older MMO's with some good water effects, and nice area design. But not at the level of most modern games like Tera, Rift or SW:The Old Republic. Best played with friends like most multiplayer focused games, however there are many friendly Kin groups (guilds) to join if you are looking for others to game with.Very Highly Recommended.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2013
												Der Herr der Ringe Online ist ein sehr episches Abenteuer RPG welches die komplette Geschichte zum Geschehen des Ringes erzählt streng nach Buchvorlage und aber auch viele Zusätze bietet.Das komplette Spiel ist Free to Play bietet zwar die möglichkeit mit einem ingame shop viel freizuschalten was jeder mit ein wenig fleiss  aber durch das sogenannte BdT - Buch der Taten nach und nach freischalten kann. Es lohnt sich aber trotzdem wenigstens einmal ca 10 euro zu investieren um VIP zu aktivieren einmal aktiviert behälst du sämtliche freischaltungen für immer und all deine Charaktere . Kenne Spieler die das  gesamte spiel kostenlos freigeschalten haben nur mit der Bewätigung vom BdT , dadurch bekommst du shoppunkte ...z.b. erkundung oder das besiegen einer gewissen anzahl von einer bestimmten art  Gegner. Dies ist ein sehr erwachsenes MMO was stetig gewartet und erweitert wird . Spielspass garantiert!! Gerne würde ich noch ellen lange Texte schreiben die mein Spielerlebniss und das Spiel selbst noch besser darstellen aber spielt selbst !!! Epische Schlachtzüge mit 12 -  24 spielern !! Auch kleine Instanzen mit 6 oder 3 Gefährten sind sehr fordend!Gerne hefe ich auch Neukömmlingen!! Also wer Interresse hat ^^    Ich selbst habe schon über 3000 Spielstunden LotRO !! P.S.LotRO bietet auch PvM player vs Monster bedeutet entweder du spielst mit deinem selbst erstellten Helden oder du erstellst dir dein Monster (ork , Warg , Spinne etc ) und stellst dich auf die seite Sarumans!

												It's a standard MMORPG, made better if you're a fan of the lore however don't expect to be able to play totally free, for free players you can reach level 50, but questing areas stop being free at level 30, you have to pay to unlock those areas. There is even a cap on your gold that you need to pay to take off, getting a mount is achievable in-game but you must first pay to unlock the riding skill. I recommend this game for a "trial", and if you like it, sub to it, staying free will actually cost you more in the long run.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The Lord of the Rings Online is actually a fairly good MMO. It offers a beautiful world set in Tolkien's fantastic Middle Earth. Though not always correct in terms of lore, LOTRO still offers a great, basic MMO. The design and gameplay are good, music is nice too, but unfortunately it quickly becomes a little boring, and though the game is set to be Free-to-Play, it is much more like Pay-to-Win once you reach a certain level. Still though - if you enjoy ME, you can have a great weekend stroling through the Shire, the Blue Mountains or Bree, but do not expect to be able to past Rivendell. That is basically endgame without paying anything in-game. I would have loved to visit Moria!

												This game is pretty much the best mmorpg out there so far its hard to do the negative stuff but here I go:the game wont alow u to change gender for the dwarfs,in monster play you cant switch weapons or change what you are wearing,and in monsterplay id like more customization,plus the abbility to play as a nazgul would be nice since apparently there are more than nine of them, and finaly there are more free peoples that you should be able to play than what there is.Now the pros:lots of customization in free peoples,endless fun and quests,lots of adventures,and plenty of people play this game to where youll never be alone,you cant have nothing on you even if u take off what you have on so this game is very modest,leveling up is really fun,and lastly theres all of middle earth to explore for the first time(not counting the lego lord of the rings video game).If running around fighting and killing is your favorite,or seteling down and having a nice home sounds more like your cup of tea then give this game a try.All in all this game has become very important to me and I recommend it to anyone looking for a new game to try out.What I like about it is the fact that you can team up to do things.have fun exploring middle earth (5,000 stars)!By the way im pipon the leader of a kinship named the finders.

												I would recomend this game to anyone who enjoys mmorpg's, I'm not a big fan of many of them myself, I did enjoy lotro for its unique perspective on the tolkien universe however, it has an art style that in my opinion makes up for the sometimes dull graphics. It also has one of the largest, if not the largest open world map that keeps expanding as new updates come out. Now, I only got up to level 20 in this game, because its at that point that grinding becomes more and more necessary to get to a high enough level to clear dungeons, unless you have a party, which I did not. I look fondly on the days that I played this game, adventuring all over the bree lands, going on a stroll through the shire, wandering the woods and mountainous terrain of ered luin, if nothing else its at least worth a try.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Taking place during the events of the Lord of the Rings Trilogy, you take the role as a <Man/Dwarf/Hobbit/Elf/(Beorning, though that ain't for F2Ps)> <Insert Class Here>  who isn't nearly as heroic as Frodo or Aragorn, despite the fact that you kill more bad dudes than either put together. Then again, I suppose "Dankbooms Fartwillow" isn't exactly the name bards will write too many ballads after.Lord of the Rings Online is a MMORPG made by Turbine, developers of Dungeons and Dragons Online and... well, actually, that's it. While you may have some sort of stigma against companies that only work off of liscensed material, know that Turbine really did a damn good job at creating a lore-friendly Middle Earth. Sure, some aspects are a little skewed, but what kind of RPG would you have without some sort of mages? C'mon, let's be honest.Jump in as one of the Free Peoples of Middle Earth... or join the war as an Orc in Monster Play! Finally, you can kill all the hobbitses you want! Interestingly, LOTRO's "health" system is rather unique in theme (not exactly mechanically, though) as your "health points" are called "Morale". As such, healing abilities are less like "Cure Light Wounds" and more along the line of "Bolster Courage". So, yeah, Minstrels are the go-to healing class. And being in scenarios where you feel "Dread" end up lowering your max health and stats, while areas of "Hope" (usually when you're nearby hallmark characters like Gandalf or Elrond) will give you increased health and damage capabilities.Overall, not a bad online game. The playerbase is also slightly more mature than most other online games, as you'll find more diehard LOTR fans than "gamers" playing the game.

Posted: December 20, 2015
												A truly magical creation, built over decades by people who clearly love the books by JRRT, and fantasy in general. One can hardly fault these good people for needing to make microtransactionas and pay-to-play content in the mid->high ranges of the game. After all, we get to feast on their beautifully wrought landscapes and intricate quests, they should be able to eat too! Of particular good quality is the Shire. If nothing else, it's worth a download and free play just to experience the love that went into making their version of the Shire. Truly enchanting. 9/10.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												A decent MMO for wasting time, classes are built more towards small party and soloing and the quests are pretty faithful to 'at least you tried' tiers to keeping with the books.  No clue about the expansions as a few of them look like they just put fan favorite characters where they wanted them.  However the worst part of this game is the same problem that Dungeons and Dragons Online has where many esential dungeons or grind spots are locked right from the start which is terrible and forces loads more grinding than someone witha  money pass.  And yet these areas are few and far between making only a few areas into massive grind fests.  The absolute worst thing however is the Hobbit's starting area, the music hills and enemies get old quick.  Other than that have fun playing one of the best WoW clones out there.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												This is surely the most beautiful and in every way perfect MMORPG. Playing this won't be boring even after thousands of hours played. Of course there are awesome quests, but also very nice crafting system, instances, housing and others. The most powerful attribute of this game is definitely world of beautiful environments, places you may know from movies and books, but also large amount of new places, places that will make♥♥♥♥♥♥yourself of their darkness. It's awesome game indeed, but still there is one bad thing - the higher your level is, the more awesome the game is, so there are some little boring parts in the introduction, especially if you play as a hobbit. Thankgod this part is short and it's followed by thrilling story and side quests, hobbies and stuff, like you've never seen. Maybe it can get boring again if you'll be low leveled and you'll need to level up with no quests left, but quest packs and expansions can fix it, and they are not expensive at all, you can even buy them for game cash, not real money. Well, this game is my first love, i recommend it to all of you!

												Been playing this game since the beginning. Over the years I have watched it grow and improve. For the age this game is, The graphics are beautifully put together. All the iconic landmarks are in game up to Helms Deep. Highly enjoyable and addictive as you always want to progress onto the next major landmark. Follows Tolkeins well known storyline but also has side stories that are not mentoned in the book to keep it interesting and less predictable. Can be played both Solo and in group (Fellowship). Plenty of different classes to choose from all with their own unique style of gameplay. Would recommend this to anyone who is a fan of Lord Of The Rings.Main Character Name - SephariemRace - ElfClass - HunterLevel - 95Server - VilyaKinship - Shield Of EriadorRank - Leader

Posted: July 2, 2014
												I will say there is nothing new or incredibly innovative about this game, but what it does it manages to do well and with a polish that is surprisingly addictive. I would recomend this to people who want to try a new MMO, especially since it is free. As far as the microtransactions go, it is really more of a problem for those who wish to try and max out their character. To the casual player, the annoyances are in having two locked classes and having difficulty with mounts, but both of these can be overcome by using the ingame achievement system to get enough points (for free) to purchase the relevant products. Quest packs (large scale ones that is) are generally too expensive to be worth the time it would take to earn the points to get them however.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The Lord of the Rings Online is actually a fairly good MMO. It offers a beautiful world set in Tolkien's fantastic Middle Earth. Though not always correct in terms of lore, LOTRO still offers a great, basic MMO. The design and gameplay are good, music is nice too, but unfortunately it quickly becomes a little boring, and though the game is set to be Free-to-Play, it is much more like Pay-to-Win once you reach a certain level. Still though - if you enjoy ME, you can have a great weekend stroling through the Shire, the Blue Mountains or Bree, but do not expect to be able to past Rivendell. That is basically endgame without paying anything in-game. I would have loved to visit Moria!

There are bugs as is with any free to play, i have screenshots in many areas that you "aren't supposed to be in". So full exploration, 1000's of quests. Lots of story that you don't get if you are a movie lover and haven't read the book series. Either way, it's fun. My time on Withywindle has been amazing, I lead the Stoned Trolls kin and know alot of people on that server, it is recommended as well. If you ask me overall, i give it a 9/10 if you can stand the grind and don't mind it like i do, 10/10. :) Good luck, and may you quest valiantly.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2013
												I find this to be one of the best MMORPGs I've ever played. The game is based off the works of J.R.R. Tolkien and takes place in Middle-Earth, making it one of the largest MMOs made. The game's pretty generous when it comes to free-to-play content, I've been playing it for free for two years now until I spent some of my extra Steam funds on this game. The game has a lot of free content for players leveled 1-30, and quest packs (which are purchased through in-game funds that can be bought with real money or earned through in-game "achievements") can help you progress even further. Unlike most MMOs, I feel fully immersed when I play this game, the artwork is very beautiful, it's better to take your time playing this game instead of rushing through the game to get to the level cap (100). I HIGHLY recommend this to anyone who's a fan of LOTRO, MMOs, or both.EDIT: Changed the level cap from "95" to "100" due to an update

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Lord of The Rings Online is a fantastic MMO for world emersion and roleplaying opportunities for anyone who is well versed in Tolkien lore. However, if you are a casual fan of the Lord of The Rings series or perhaps enjoy playing games to make up your own world, then stay away. Let me be clear that the people who play this game are no worse than any other group online. They just have one, very hard to ignore, flaw.The thing is that there is a much larger push to understand and adhere to lore outside the game than I have seen anywhere else online. This means that if you're not already a master of Tolkien lore you can expect either: A: Hours of research or B: To be confused by the majority of roleplay interactions and treated as an inferior player. I know, as I fall into this category.This does not mean the community itself is flawed. On the contrary, they mostly ignore anyone who does not directly approach them. It's worth noting that I played on a roleplay server, so it's likely not as bad on other servers.Lord of The Rings may not be the right game for you, but if you have a moderate knowledge of the Tolkien universe then I suggest you download it and give it a try. The game itself isn't half bad. Even with all the community issues, I still plan to play. (It's worth noting that when I began playing this game, it was not through Steam, but rather from the game webpage, so I havent had much experiance with the Steam version)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												This is honestly the best game I've ever played and I never get tired of it. I've actually played thousands of hours not reflected in my Steam account, because I used to play LOTRO downloaded from Turbine's website until I switched to Steam (I started playing LOTRO around mid-2009 and switched to Steam last year at around level 60)I'll just do a quick pros and cons list before I go into detail:Pros: -Huge open world sandbox, literally endless things to do-Great epic storyline quests to follow-Quite literally thousands of side quests-Slayer and explorer deeds to complete on the side-Reputation factions give some decent rewards-The world itself is massive, great for people who love to wander around exploring-Even for non-LOTR nerds this is a fantastic and immersive MMO experience-Community is helpful and respectful for the most part-Great cosmetic and crafting system-Free to playCons:-Housing system is eeehh. You have to keep paying upkeep for a house that really isn't that impressive (I have a deluxe house and it's still not that great, regular houses are just...no), and your decorations are locked into "hotspots".-Character models look very sad. Way outdated graphics.-Some quests are great (mostly the epic ones) and have interesting things going on. Most are your classic "Kill # of (monster) or gather # of (item) because I can't because (reason)". Can get VERY grindy. -Other quests have very vague objectives and are hard to figure out. -This was in the pros, but the world is massive. It's also in the cons because if you don't have some porting skills, you can face some loooong long horse rides to places. Oh, and if you're not a subscriber you have to buy the riding skill.-Some solo quests that *say* they're for your level, have turned out to be impossible for that level. I've had to return to some quests 4 levels later to complete them. Speaking of that...-PvMP can be really tough and it's definitely not well-balanced.-The Free to Play truly only lasts until you hit about level 35 and need to move on from the Lone-Lands and into either the North Downs or Trollshaws (both buyable individually)My favorite part about this game? It's the freedom and amount of things you can do. I'm level 70 and I still return to very low-level areas just to do random side quests or even just explore.The world is so vast, dynamic, and various that I always find new places to enjoy the scenery or do some solo or group role-playing.The music is epic and beautiful, though the constant combat music starting and restarting every time you fight something can get annoying and I do wish there was a way to turn it off.This game is more of a sandbox than anything I've ever played, even Skyrim. The amount of things to do is just ENDLESS. You can do side quests, build your reputation with different factions, complete slaying and exploring deeds, do the epic storyline quests, work on your personal vocation skills, you can do all of that and more in each and every area of the game.  If you love the freedom of doing your own thing whenever you want with little restrictions, this is the perfect game for you. If you have a free spirit and a heart for adventure, this is the perfect game for you. You build your own story, character, and legacy in this game.As far as subscribing goes, I usually will individually buy each expansion pack and have seen no need to subscribe. By subscribing I would probably save myself more money in the end, however, by not subscribing I can wait as long as I want before buying a new quest pack or area. Pretty much everything the VIPs get is available for purchase, so that's awesome.One of my favorite aspects of the game, though, is the seasonal and community events. They have fall, winter, spring, and summer festivals each with their own unique themes, activities, and locations. There are other events like Hobnanigans and other socially-organized events like Weatherstock (player music concert atop Weathertop). It's not without its flaws, though. The graphics, especially for characters, are very outdated looking and sometimes they take away from my immersive experience. And for the hardcore Tolkien followers, though it does follow the book, obviously a lot of side characters and other things are completely made up for the sake of the game.TL;DR Classic MMO with endless things to do, perfect for the LOTR nerd.

												An extremely long game. While you can still play in free to play mode it involves countless hours of grinding an area or doing quest where you might have outlevel the enemies. The grind gives you points that make quests, expansion and instances available. The true version of the game lies in the VIP mode where you pay a subscription it gives you access to all the quest while you still have to grind areas to get expansions the grind is significantly reduced. The story is engaging but more could have been done to diversify it and make it more engaging. You can forget doing low level instances if you are not part of a kin but even if you play alone and lvl up you will quickly find players in the same position as you trying instances. The weapons and crafting system lets you trade anything with players at any given time and is extermely helpful. You don't have to be a lotr fan to be able to enjoy the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Got the game, loved it at first playing as an elf hunter kiling those cave crawlers and evil dwarfs. Stopped playing  shortly after since i was a massive noob at MMORPGS. Come back decide to become premium and purchase stuff, start actually getting into it, realise it was one of the best MMORPGS i've ever played. Shooting down goblins from afar and being able to down several foes in melee aswell while getting some sweet loot for your character. The leveling takes time compared to other games like WoW which is why i like this better. In-game deed log and turbine points awarded for completing them makes the game so much more worth playing. You want that riding at level 2 for 95 tp? Why not do some deeds and have it by level 10. What makes this game so good is that you can either play it normally and earn tp to buy stuff through the store or you can spend a little bit of money to enhance your character/characters while leveling or w/e you're doing. It's not really a pay to win game seeing as it's not like those other ones where you pay and  it's pretty much a pvp game. This is more questing, leveling and lore until max level. Once at max level you then can choose to go into the pvp zone or go into monster play. In the end it's totally worth getting if you're the kind of person who likes to spend time on a game hours on end grinding stuff and hacking n slashing those foes down until you can get into the next zone of leveling. De a 10/10 for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												I hate MMORPGs and I love LOTRO. Big reasons why:1. I care about the world. There's the Shire to explore, including Buckland and the Old Woods, there's Bree and its surroundings, and it all feels familiar and real. That's something you can't get with Everquest, because who cares about any of those cities or regions and whether they get destroyed by some lich king? LOTRO has a world I've wanted to explore for years, before there was such a thing as an MMORPG. No other online game can give me that.2. No pkilling. LOTRO seems to sense on some level that the people in their community aren't looking for the same experience as the Warcraft people. Interaction with other players is entirely cooperative and voluntary. For PVP competitions, there's a place called the Ettenmoors, but in actual practice, not many players use the Ettenmoors. If they want to kill other players and teabag the corpses, they'd be playing WOW. And even the social interaction is decent. At least it was for me. I was playing on Withywindle, which was a European server with a lot of UK users.3. Free to play was too good to resist. And once I'd immersed myself in the game, I had no trouble throwing some dollars at Turbine for some perks. They deserve a lot more than I've spent, really. A free user will be limited to the lower level lands, which include the Shire, Bree, Ered Luin (which I didn't know much about, but has lively dwarf and elf populations), and the Lone-Lands, where you can visit Weathertop. That's PLENTY for a free user to do. Especially the Shire, which is worth spending hours in just for the atmosphere.Anyway, even though the game interface is a little antiquated by 2015 standards, LOTRO is still amazing and it's the only MMORPG I will ever play. I'd recommend it to people who avoid MMORPGs but love Tolkien.

												I would recomend this game to anyone who enjoys mmorpg's, I'm not a big fan of many of them myself, I did enjoy lotro for its unique perspective on the tolkien universe however, it has an art style that in my opinion makes up for the sometimes dull graphics. It also has one of the largest, if not the largest open world map that keeps expanding as new updates come out. Now, I only got up to level 20 in this game, because its at that point that grinding becomes more and more necessary to get to a high enough level to clear dungeons, unless you have a party, which I did not. I look fondly on the days that I played this game, adventuring all over the bree lands, going on a stroll through the shire, wandering the woods and mountainous terrain of ered luin, if nothing else its at least worth a try.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												An extremely long game. While you can still play in free to play mode it involves countless hours of grinding an area or doing quest where you might have outlevel the enemies. The grind gives you points that make quests, expansion and instances available. The true version of the game lies in the VIP mode where you pay a subscription it gives you access to all the quest while you still have to grind areas to get expansions the grind is significantly reduced. The story is engaging but more could have been done to diversify it and make it more engaging. You can forget doing low level instances if you are not part of a kin but even if you play alone and lvl up you will quickly find players in the same position as you trying instances. The weapons and crafting system lets you trade anything with players at any given time and is extermely helpful. You don't have to be a lotr fan to be able to enjoy the game.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Lord of the Rings fan? Like to play MMO's? This game is the best to play with.  Sure it's not as vivid or lively as other well known titles but  depth wise it's very good.It's more associated to the novels than to the Peter Jackson films but either way it's a good game for any LOTR fan.Like I said it's not very lively you wont find hundreds or players swarming the cities but I have passed good time just going at my own pace and exploring middle earth.The crafting / vocations system is also very good.  Coming from WoW i got tired of the simple, easy to grind professions systems that I could max out in a couple hours to have no use at all in the end game.  The crafting system in Lotro offers multiple out put recipes and with its chance for pieces to crit and become improved to highest level quality makes you wants to craft your heart out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Some other reviews have blatant misinformation in regards to what is and isn't free, and what the model is. You play the game, you unlock achievements such as explore X zone, 10 turbine points(the cash shop currency) By the time I hit level 20 on one character I had enough to buy the next quest pack. The achievements to earn turbine points are many, finish all quests, kill x of each monster, it was fun, added extra goals and exploration to each zone and I thoroughly enjoyed it.If you like me, made a second character and leveled it 20(which requires no $$) you'd have a good chunk of turbine points to spend on the rest of the game. You do not have to pay to play, unless you are super lazy and do only the bare minimum quests to level. The game is dated, and looks dated, but I think it still has a charming feel to it, and I certainly did feel like I was a part of middle earth. I value quality of content over aesthetics, and this game delivers. Housing, quests, epic questlines, legendary items, mounts, tons of stuff involved. The only reason I am no longer playing is that I just do not have the time to devote to three different MMO's.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												An MMORPG is only as good as the guild you're in to a large extent. Lord of the Rings Online is a good MMO with a good Freemium model, in fact it was the first hugely successful Freemium model and several other games have taken queues from it. I think of all Freemium models, LOTRO did it the best. The story is engaging and has you crisscrossing over the paths of the Fellowship across Middle Earth. The zones alone are well worth it for the big lore nerds out there. If you can find a good guild, this game has a lot to offer, but it also falls victim to the same shortcomings of all MMOs.Is it worth playing? If you're a Lord of the Rings fan looking for an MMORPG, absolutely. If you're looking for an MMORPG that does something hugely different, move along, this does nothing groundbreaking.

												One of the few MMOs I fell in love with and played for an extended period of time.  The story of this game is really great and the atmosphere is just awesome.
